text: Overview
This document explains how to edit levels, create entity types, and place entities in the SplineGame level editor.

SplineGame levels are built around Bezier splines. Each level has a spline path defined by control points, and entities (enemies, triggers, player spawns) are placed along or near the spline. The data is organized into a hierarchy of tables in the database.
Data Architecture
The level system uses a nested table hierarchy:

GameLevels (top-level)
  |-- Level Name (text)
  |-- SplineGameLevel (subtable, one row per level)
        |-- EntityTools (table ref -> splinegame_entity_tools)
        |-- Points (subtable) - the spline control points
        |     |-- Order (number)
        |     |-- Position (vec2)
        |     |-- TangentIn (vec2)
        |     |-- TangentOut (vec2)
        |
        |-- Entities (subtable) - placed entities along the spline
              |-- Order (number)
              |-- ParamT (number, 0-1 position on spline)
              |-- Position (vec2, world position)
              |-- EntityTable (table ref -> which entity table)
              |-- EntityRowId (text -> specific row in entity table)
              |-- DataJson (text, per-instance overrides)
Entity System
Entity Base Schema

All entity tables inherit from splinegame_entity_base (a system table). This base schema provides four columns that every entity type shares: Id, Name, UiAsset, and Scale. The UiAsset column references a .bdui file that defines how the entity looks in the editor and in-game. Scale controls the entity's render size.
Current Entity Types
The project currently has three entity types, each as a separate table that inherits from the base schema:
Enemies - Enemy entities with UiAsset (ui/enemy.bdui). Contains 3 rows (variants of enemies). Registered in EntityTools as "Enemies".
Player - Player spawn entities with UiAsset (ui/player.bdui). Has an extra local column "MoreData". Registered in EntityTools as "Player".
Triggers - Trigger zones (e.g. "Room Trigger") for gameplay events. Registered in EntityTools as "Triggers".
Entity Tools Table

The splinegame_entity_tools table is a system table that acts as a registry of available entity types. Each row maps a display name to an entity table. The level editor reads this table to populate the entity placement toolbar. Each level's SplineGameLevel subtable has an EntityTools column referencing this table, which determines which entity types are available for that level.

How To: Create a New Level
Open the GameLevels table in Derp.Doc.
Add a new row. Set the "Level Name" to something descriptive (e.g. "Level 3").
Click into the "SplineGameLevel" subtable cell. This opens the level's subtable, which has one row automatically created.
Set the "EntityTools" column to point to the splinegame_entity_tools table. This links the entity type registry to your level.
Use the spline editor view to add control points to the "Points" subtable. Each point has a Position, TangentIn, and TangentOut that define the Bezier curve.
Place entities along the spline using the "Entities" subtable (see "Placing Entities" below).
How To: Edit the Spline Path
The spline path is defined by the Points subtable. Each point has:
Order - Determines the sequence of points along the spline. Points are evaluated in ascending order.
Position - The world-space (x, y) coordinate of the control point.

TangentIn / TangentOut - Control the curvature of the Bezier spline entering and leaving the point. These are relative offsets from the point position. Adjusting tangents changes how smooth or sharp the curve is at that point.

In the visual spline editor, you can drag points and their tangent handles directly. The editor writes back to the Points subtable automatically. You can also edit the numeric values directly in the table view for precise positioning.
How To: Place Entities in a Level
Entities are placed in a level via the Entities subtable. Each entity placement has:
Order - Render/processing order for the entity in the level.
ParamT - A value from 0.0 to 1.0 indicating position along the spline. 0.0 is the start of the spline, 1.0 is the end. This is the primary way entities are anchored to the path.
Position - The world-space position of the entity. When placed via the visual editor, this is computed from ParamT and an optional offset from the spline.
EntityTable - A TableRef pointing to which entity table this instance comes from (e.g. Enemies, Player, or Triggers).
EntityRowId - The specific row ID within the entity table. This determines which enemy variant, player type, or trigger to use.
DataJson - Optional JSON for per-instance data overrides. Defaults to "{}" when no overrides are needed.

In the visual editor, select an entity type from the toolbar (populated from EntityTools), then click on or near the spline to place it. The editor will compute the nearest ParamT and Position automatically.
How To: Create a New Entity Type
To add a completely new category of entities (e.g. "Collectibles", "Hazards", "NPCs"):
Step 1: Create the Entity Table
Create a new table (e.g. "Collectibles").
Set its inheritance source to splinegame_entity_base. This gives it the standard Id, Name, UiAsset, and Scale columns automatically.
Add any custom columns specific to this entity type (e.g. "PointValue" for collectibles, "DamageAmount" for hazards). These are local columns that won't affect other entity types.
Add rows for each variant of this entity type (e.g. "Gold Coin", "Silver Coin", "Health Pack"). Set their Name, UiAsset (.bdui file), and Scale.
Step 2: Register in Entity Tools
Open the splinegame_entity_tools table.
Add a new row with a display Name (e.g. "Collectibles") and set the EntitiesTable column to point to your new table.
The new entity type will now appear in the level editor's entity placement toolbar for all levels.
Step 3: Add Entity Variants to the Table

Each row in your entity table represents a distinct variant that can be placed in levels. For example, the Enemies table has 3 rows — each is a different enemy type that can be independently placed and configured. When placing entities in the level editor, you'll select both the entity category (from EntityTools) and the specific variant (row) within that category.

Tips
Use the visual spline editor for intuitive point and entity placement — it handles ParamT and Position calculations automatically.
Entity tables that inherit from splinegame_entity_base can add any number of custom columns for type-specific data (health, speed, damage, etc.).
The DataJson field on placed entities can override per-instance properties without creating a new row in the entity table.
Keep spline point Order values sequential (1, 2, 3...) for predictable path behavior. Gaps are allowed but may cause confusion.
After creating a new entity type and registering it in EntityTools, run an export to regenerate code that references the new data.
